paragraphs.title: Reminder
paragraphs.p:
The effects of the elementary row operations on the determinant are:
swapping rows
\det(\text{new}) = -\det(\text{old});
multiplying a row by constant k
\det(\text{new}) = k\det(\text{old});
adding a multiple of one row to another
\det(\text{new}) = \det(\text{old}).

statement.p:
Consider the general 3\times 3 matrix
A = \begin{bmatrix} a_{11} \amp a_{12} \amp a_{13} \\ a_{21} \amp a_{22} \amp a_{23} \\ a_{31} \amp a_{32} \amp a_{33} \end{bmatrix}.
Each entry a_{ij} has a corresponding cofactor C_{ij}, creating a matrix of cofactors
C_A = \begin{bmatrix} C_{11} \amp C_{12} \amp C_{13} \\ C_{21} \amp C_{22} \amp C_{23} \\ C_{31} \amp C_{32} \amp C_{33} \end{bmatrix}.
The transpose of this matrix is called the (classical) adjoint of A.
Write out the (1,1) entry of the product A\utrans{C}_A as a formula in the entries of A and C_A. Does the result look familiar?
What do you think the other diagonal entries of A\utrans{C}_A are?

ol.li: Suppose \det A = 0. If you apply some elementary row operation to A, what is the determinant of the new matrix? (Consider each of the three kinds of operations.)
If \det A = 0 and you perform a whole sequence of row operations to A, what is the determinant of the last matrix in the sequence?

li.p: Recall that if A is invertible, then it can be row reduced to I (). If \det A = 0, could A be invertible?

hint.p: Use the previous part of this activity.

li.p: Conversely, if A is invertible, could \det A = 0?

ol.label: alph
ol.li: Suppose \det A \neq 0. Is there any elementary row operation you can apply to A so that the new matrix has determinant 0? (Consider each of the three kinds of operations.)
If \det A \neq 0 and you perform a whole sequence of row operations to A, could the last matrix in the sequence have determinant 0?

li.p: Recall that if a matrix is singular ( not invertible), then it is not possible to row reduce it to I, and so its RREF must have a row of zeros. If \det A \neq 0, could A be singular?

hint.p: Use the previous part of this activity.

li.p: Conversely, if A is singular, is \det A \neq 0 possible?

statement.p: Recall that for matrix A and elementary matrix E, the result of EA is the same as the result of performing an elementary row operation on A (namely, the operation corresponding to E). Verify the formula \det (EA) = (\det E)(\det A) for each of the three types of elementary matrices E (assuming A to be a square matrix of the same size as E).

ul.li: To verify a formula, consider LHS and RHS separately, and argue that they equal the same value. Do not work with the proposed equality directly, since you don't know it's an equality yet.
Do not just use examples; think abstractly instead.

For each type of E, on the LHS consider the product of matrices EA and how its determinant compares to \det A using the rules for how row operations affect determinant (explored in the activities in , and recalled for you at the top of this activity section). For this, think of \det A = \det (\text{old}) and \det (EA) = \det (\text{new}). Then, on the RHS, consider the value of \det E and the corresponding product of numbers (\det E)(\det A).

statement.p:
In this exercise, we will verify the general formula \det (MN) = (\det M)(\det N) in the case that M is invertible (assuming M and N to be square matrices of the same size).
Recall that every invertible matrix can be expressed as a product of elementary matrices (). For now, suppose that M (which we have assumed invertible) can be expressed as a product of three elementary matrices, say M = E_1 E_2 E_3. Use the formula from
to verify that \det (E_1 E_2 E_3 N) = (\det E_1)(\det E_2)(\det E_3)(\det N).
Start with the LHS and apply the formula \det (EA) = (\det E)(\det A) one step at a time. What are you using for A at each step?
Now use the formula from
to verify that (\det E_1)(\det E_2)(\det E_3)(\det N) = \bbrac{\det (E_1 E_2 E_3)}(\det N).
Make sure you understand why parts (a) and (b) together verify that \det (MN) = (\det M)(\det N) for this M.
Do you think the calculations of the previous parts would work no matter how many E_i's are required to express M as a product of elementary matrices?

If matrix A is invertible, by definition this means that A\inv{A} = I.
Determine the value of \det (A\inv{A}) from the equality A\inv{A} = I.
Starting with your answer to the previous part of this activity, use the formula \det (MN) = (\det M)(\det N) from to find a formula for \det (\inv{A}) in terms of \det A.

A fraction 1/A does not make sense for matrices. However, \det A is just a number, so you can do all the normal algebra you would like with it!
In this activity, we extend the general formula \det (MN) = (\det M)(\det N) to also be valid in case that M is singular (assuming M and N to be square matrices of the same size).
Recall that if M is singular ( not invertible), then every product MN is singular (Statement of ).
